explanation: formal; a small room, especially a waiting room, that leads into a larger, more important room
sentence: The ministers waited for their meeting in the Cabinet anteroom.
sentence_gap: The ministers waited for their meeting in the Cabinet ________.

explanation: the state of being another person's slave
sentence: The slaves were kept in bondage until their death.
sentence_gap: The slaves were kept in _______ until their death.

explanation: (of something) that must be done; necessary by law or a rule
sentence: The law made wearing seat belts in cars compulsory.
sentence_gap: The law made wearing seat belts in cars __________.

explanation: to understand the meaning of something in a particular way
sentence: That comment could be construed in either of two ways.
sentence_gap: That comment could be _________ in either of two ways.

explanation: to send something in the same envelope or parcel as something else
sentence: Please enclose a curriculum vitae with your application.
sentence_gap: Please _______ a curriculum vitae with your application.

sentence: His latest book has received glowing reviews.
sentence_gap: His latest book has received _______ reviews.

explanation: formal; until now or until a particular time
sentence: Mira revealed hitherto unsuspected talents on the dance floor.
sentence_gap: Mira revealed ________ unsuspected talents on the dance floor.

explanation: a small insect that lives on the bodies of humans and animals
sentence: Flies, lice, gadflies and mosquitoes are the worst of the insect plagues.
sentence_gap: Flies, ____, gadflies and mosquitoes are the worst of the insect plagues.

explanation: to suggest something as a basic fact or principle from which a further idea is formed or developed
sentence: Most religions posit the existence of life after death.
sentence_gap: Most religions _____ the existence of life after death.

explanation: a rule for action or behavior, especially obtained from moral thought
sentence: This policy goes against common precepts of decency.
sentence_gap: This policy goes against common ________ of decency.

explanation: showing no respect for a god or a religion, often through language
sentence: His letter is too profane to print, but it is very funny, too.
sentence_gap: His letter is too _______ to print, but it is very funny, too.

explanation: a short fight in which people push each other
sentence: Two police officers were injured in scuffles with demonstrators at Sunday's protest.
sentence_gap: Two police officers were injured in ________ with demonstrators at Sunday's protest.

explanation: informal; a lot of very small broken pieces
sentence: The city was bombed to smithereens during the war.
sentence_gap: The city was bombed to ___________ during the war.

explanation: (of speech, writing, style, etc.) boring and too serious about its subject matter; swollen; containing more water than usual
sentence: As a writer he was apt to be turgid and prolix, and there was a somewhat un-English element of ostentation in his manner.
sentence_gap: As a writer he was apt to be ______ and prolix, and there was a somewhat un-English element of ostentation in his manner.

explanation: the amount that is wasted; the fact of losing or destroying something, especially because it has been used or dealt with carelessly
sentence: Water companies will have to cut down on wastage.
sentence_gap: Water companies will have to cut down on _______.
